interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information === Product Title: Mr. Holmes [DVD + Digital] Review Date: 2015/11/25 Store: Ian McKellen (Actor), Laura Linney (Actor), Bill Condon (Director) & 0 more Rated: PG Format: DVD Categories: Movies & TV, Genre for Featured Categories, Drama Product Description: ["Mr. Holmes is a new twist on the world’s most famous detective. In 1947, in his remote seaside farmhouse, an aging Sherlock Holmes (Ian McKellen, Academy Award (r) nominee, 2002, Best Actor in a Supporting Role, The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring) tends to his bees, with only the company of his housekeeper (Laura Linney, Academy Award (r) nominee, 2001, Best Actress in a Leading Role, You Can Count on Me) and her charming young son, Roger. Grappling with the diminishing powers of his mind, Holmes comes to rely upon the boy as he revisits the circumstances of the unsolved case that forced him into retirement, and searches for answers to the mysteries of life and love – before it's too late."] Average Rating: 4.3 Product Details: {'Genre': 'Crime', 'Format': 'Multiple Formats, Color, Widescreen, NTSC', 'Contributor': 'Laura Linney, Bill Condon, Hiroyuki Sanada, Milo Parker, Jeffrey Hatcher, Ian McKellen, Mitch Cullin', 'Language': 'English', 'Runtime': '1 hour and 44 minutes', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'PG (Parental Guidance Suggested)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.7 x 7.5 x 5.4 inches; 2.4 Ounces', 'Audio Description': 'English', 'Item model number': '35225428', 'Director': 'Bill Condon', 'Media Format': 'Multiple Formats, Color, Widescreen, NTSC', 'Run time': '1 hour and 44 minutes', 'Release date': 'November 10, 2015', 'Actors': 'Ian McKellen, Laura Linney, Milo Parker, Hiroyuki Sanada', 'Studio': 'Lionsgate Home Entertainment', 'Writers': 'Mitch Cullin, Jeffrey Hatcher', 'Number of discs': '1'} Review Text: The DVD makes is incredibly hard to start the movie, and once there, if you stop or turn of the movie for any reason, you can start it back up, either then or later, you have to go through all the 4 minutes of the DVD's "starting" garbage.

I stopped half way into it last night, had to restart, wasted half an hour with scene selection (having to go through the 4 minutes of "startup" in between each selection), the when I finally found the place, accidentally pressed stop instead of play, which reset the DVD for the 10th time. So I clicked eject. So I can't say how good the movie is but this DVD is horribly made.

My DVD player is perfectly capable of remembering where it left off other DVDs, even weeks later. The studio spent tons of money on the movie then apparently gave the DVD & its menus to be made by their unemployed nephew for $20. Review Title: So I can't say how good the movie is but this DVD is HORRIBLY made. Rating: 1.0 --------------------------------------------------

profile:
**User Profile Summary:**

- **Primary Interest**: Strong affinity for science fiction television, particularly series featuring fantasy elements and complex narratives. The user also enjoys content with iconic literary characters, such as Sherlock Holmes.
- **Content Preferences**: Prefers series and films that are part of well-established franchises, demonstrating a preference for enduring storylines and characters.
- **Format Preference**: Favors DVD collections, reflecting an appreciation for physical media and a desire for high-quality formats. Recent experiences reveal frustration with poorly designed DVDs, impacting the overall enjoyment of the content.
- **Quality Appreciation**: Exhibits a keen eye for packaging and presentation. While highly values professional production quality, the user does express dissatisfaction when encountering subpar DVD usability, particularly issues related to navigation and playback.
- **Engagement with Series**: Actively engages with multiple seasons of shows and has rewatched entire series multiple times, indicating a deep enjoyment and investment in extended narratives.
- **Rating Behavior**: Generally rates products positively when they meet high expectations for quality and presentation; however, the user is not afraid to express disappointment (1.0 for the recent DVD purchase) when products fall short, indicating a strong commitment to quality media experiences.

The user maintains a consistent focus on fulfilling and well-produced content while being critical of production and usability flaws in physical media.
